It is the oldest church in Malmö. Built in the 14th Century, the frescos and the altar are historical treasures. Well worth making the time to visit.

Apparently the oldest building in this area, the church is lovely. Our tour guide told us that it was originally a Catholic Church, ornately decorated inside, but when it became a Protestant church, they painted over a lot of that. There’s a small area they haven’t painted over.
Beautiful church in Malmo, well worth a visit and a walk around. Free entry and very quite, me and my wife enjoyed it
Very old exterior and one very old section inside. The main part is white, clean and modern. Very centrally located and welcoming.

We were lucky to visit when the organist was in full flow the sound filled every corner of the building, the acoustics are amazing. I believe that this is a Lutheran church so it is not as ornate as Catholic churches but still nice to visit.
This chuch is amazing and a fantastic piece of Malmös history, it is very close to the central station (walking distance).
Not many cathedrals have had their tower falling down not once but twice. Fantastic acoustic and interesting artefacts.

If you like old church architecture then you would get lost in this grand building. I only walked around on the outside as it was undergoing some renovations. However, it was fun just seeing the detailed architecture put into the old buildings of yesteryear.

St. Peter’s Church in Malmo is the oldest building in the city. This 14th century building is famous for its high wooden altar, one of the highest in Europe. The church also has a chapel attached to it. Worth a visit.

Too bad you can’t get in since the interior is undergoing renovations through December 2018. Much better churches to see across the bridge in Copenhagen. Better yet, go to the Roskilde Cathedral and couple it with a visit to the Viking museum nearby.

So you can see the church, it's big enough, nothing special. However, it's closed (August 2018), so they have a temporary igloo church nearby which is a bit cool..

it is an impressive and rather austere building. it could be hlped by more descriptive materials. well worth going to

The only reason I gave this a three is I didn't get a chance to see the inside sonce iy was closed under constriction. It was beautiful on the outside

It's written to be one of the oldest preserved churches in Malmo. The alter is beautiful! We just happened to walk in while a choir was rehearsing. The sound was amazing. Although they were not playing the organ, there was a sign stating they are adding to an already huge organ!
We walked in during a children's rehearsal it added to the ambiance. The church is very understated worth spending a few minutes sering
Not particularly memorable, but it has a lovely spire. Also, the altar is worth a dekko. Good for about an hour.
Interesting and informative. A church with real history and gravitas. Helpful staff who wanted to help and tell you all about the church and its history. It takes about an hour but well worth it.
Beautiful church with an organ. One of the more iconic buildings in Malmo. Take 15 minutes to walk in and take some photos.

Red and beautiful building attracts attention。It is very close to famous City Hall building so you can visit that spot too。Me and my family we got inside to see。Peaceful and simple。Spend 10-15 minutes for here pretty enough。No enterance fee。Architecture style is unique。
the building is really nice , its huge makes it visible from different places in the city , i wish the inside had the same effect of greatness you get from the outside
A lovely church different in style to those we visited in Copenhagen. Have a look at the stained glass windows showing scenes from the lives of Saints Peter and Paul.
I am short of words. Please ensure you visit the church. Dont forget to write a prayer for your loved ones. +

The church, inside, is nothing special though in the usual beautiful scandinavian style, but outside is quite interesting. They are going to renew their organ and at that point this church will have the most big organ in south Sweden.
Interesting church, quite spartan inside - but it wasn't always this way. Frescoes in the side knave quite amazing considering their age.

The light is the first thing you see- the church interior is white which combined with the light streaming in on a sunny Scandinavian day overwhelms you completely. There are well preserved frescos and rich men graves beneath the floor

While on an afternoon visit to Malmo we had the opportunity to stop in and visit the church. It really is beautiful and visitors are welcome to walk around and take pictures. I was especially impressed that the church had laid out a rainbow rug runner to support Pride Week.
Came across St. Petri's while walking back to the train station and dicovered a truely stunning church,with an interior painted white it is a very beautiful building and will worth a visit

We visited on a Sunday afternoon. We were greeted with beautiful organ music that played (remotely) during our entire visit. This is a beautiful church with a great history. Just before we exited we saw a room where they were restoring the original paintings on the walls.
I thought this church was very pretty. Extremely easy to find and get to. The inside of the church was beautiful.
Its very central location makes it easy to visit when in city. Often high class concert performances are given, so just check out the program.
Beautiful church in Malmo , extremely romantic and beautiful . What is unusual - the clean white walls , columns and arches are in heart taking contrast with golden wooden altar.

Just standing outside and looking at the spears of this structure is fantastic. Entering the big doors in front and making way into the main room makes you feel small and full of admiration. A church full of history and magnificant archhitevture. Worth a visit and maybe sit down

We visited this church mainly because it is the church where all of my wife's ancestors were christened and married going back hundred's of years including her father. The staff was exceedingly friendly and knowledgeable which greatly enhanced our short time there. I was floored
A pleasant old church near the center of Malmo. It is only a few minutes walk from the main center with the squares and is quite picturesque.
Very poor church with a very simple decoration. The bulding wasn't also very architectural itself. So if you don't have time to visit it don't worry. At least it's free of charge.

The alter and painted ceiling are really something. During our visit on a Monday, the priest held a service and it was interesting she was accompanied by a pianist who also sang solo. Only a handful in the church attended the service. Very enjoyable and well worth a visit.

Just across the Town Hall of Malme, is located this oldest building in the capital of southernmost region of Sweden, that is, the Scania. This church dates back from the early 14th century. St. Petri or St.Peter's Church has got one very interesting architectural style, so
As the oldest building in Malmö, this church definitely worth the visit because I think it has such particular Swedish style. Definitely worth to visit once in a while.

Took a day trip to Malmo (from Copenhagen) and really enjoyed the city. This church is worth a stop. It's beautiful inside and outside with an amazing altar. When we were there, there was a service getting ready to start, but you're still able to stand in the back. There was no
A well preserved gothic church with a high altar truly worth seeing. Note the list of parish preasts, an illustration of how Skåne represents a heritage of both Denmark and Sweden.

I love the old churches of Europe and this one didn't disappoint. The alter is amazing. And the building itself has very cool features. On one side I think they are called flying buttresses. Very cool. It amazes me how they built these way back when and this one is nice.
The church wasn't far from Malmo Central Station. It was only a few minutes walking away. If you arrive at Malmo Central Station, I'd highly recommend to check this church out.
A huge church in the centre of old city that is very nice. Didn't get a chance to go inside but from the outside it's majestic really and you have to visit it
This church dates back 700 years or more apparently and is worth a look. It has grave markers on the floor dating back to the 1600s and an old ante room that looks untouched for centuries.

Like most churches in Sweden, everyone is welcome to join the services. The language spoken is off course Swedish but ask the person next to you and they will give you hints. Churches have long opening hours and you can pop in for a shorter or longer visit to admire the
I liked the elegant simplicity ... and the way it is blended with the surrounding buildings ... it is just there ...

This is a very nice church. It is pleasant to visit also the inside, which is for free and it is one of these churches that does not contain many gold decorations. It is rather in a modest style, which I prefer.

Church in city centre, front of church was probably meeting of local city pickpockets group in morning, boss was give a day schcedule for his workers, looks very strange, police absents. Inside and outside was nice church, not lot of paints on walls inside, church is big, make
A working attraction that contains a beautifully restored chapel with 500 year old murals above the christening basin. Rest of church not so charming.

Really, living in Denmark this was nothing special. A very ordinary church with very ordinary old grave stones and a nice alter. I liked the boys' choir but did not have a chance to listen to them as we had to leave. Nice post cards to buy

One of the oldest churches in the south of Sweden with burials of famous Knights inside the church.My daughter was baptisted in the church.Its in the central of Malmö city."min walk from Stortorget where the statue of the Swedish warrior king Gustav the 12th are standing.So if
Not as big as other main churches but its beautiful in its own way. I also enjoyed reading a bit of the history near the entrance.

We saw it from outside, and yes, it is beautiful. It is especially interesting if you are used to a different style. However, if you've seen other churches like this, you won't get much from spending time here.

It is supposed to be the oldest structure in Malmo but it is so well maintained and beautiful inside. One chapel still has the remains of paintings on the ceilings and walls. We did worry about stepping onto those marvelous stone carvings on the floor commemorating the dead.
Beautiful place in the center of city. Nice restaurant near this church. Beautiful church and history of Malmo/Sweden.
I stopped into this lovely little church and spent some time here. I got talking to a lovely little priest. I wouldn't factor long into my day for this but it is a beautiful stop off.
Beautiful place in the center of the city, visible and accesible from all sides. I never hoped to see an Orthodox icon in a protestant church!!!
I only had a short time here but it was very quiet and peaceful. It was also very easy to find this church
The old town is not huge so it's not difficult to find this church. It's worth a quick look inside as well as a photo outside as you walk around Malmo.
This church has lot of history. Very beautiful. I love churches and this in one of the best preserved.
Not a very nice place to visit because of a lot of traffic and problem with parking spots. I would recommend another

A recommendation from the desk at the Mayfair Hotel Tunneln, which is around the corner virtually. It was cold out and nice to duck into places as we walked around. Once in the church, one got a real sense of the history of this magnificent building and historic place. Having
The architecture of this church is amazing, but once I came inside I was disappointed. it was poor and nothing special and it's a pity since it's one of the most popular attractions in Malmö.

This is a wonderful, actively used building. The design is very interesting. The church sits right in the middle of a shopping district, and you can see it from all over the city. Construction on this building was started in 1319, and you can see how additions were made to it
The church is open from 10 to 18, so it is quite easy to go inside and have a look. Very central, in the heart of the old town.

We walked around the outside and it's beautiful. Went in and they were preparing some performance from school kids. So we didn't want to disturb them too much and just walk around a bit . It was very nicely renovated inside.

Lovely church that is easy to find, open hours are sometimes difficult but it is worth it to take a little look inside. It may not be the most incredible but it is still lovely to see it when visiting Malmo.
Well worth finding time to visit as the outside is not nealy as attractive. Opening hours can be limited as it is a working church.

St Petri is the oldest church building in Malmö and the oldest one built with brick. Dating from the 14th century the interior has been remodeled several times during the 700 years. Not in any way particular in appearance or architecture, St Petri should nevertheless be seen if
In a town of so few items of true tourist worth its hard to get too excited about this church as it's not that amazing in any particular way. It was one of the top 10 things to see in Malmo
One of the oldest building in Malmo this church is almost entirely built out of brick and has a spire spanning over 100 metres. (344 feet). Lots of great photos to ve taken here.
We visited this church on a Monday within the publicised opening times and it was not open. This was disappointing. It is, however, worth a visit to look at the architecture from the outside.
This church was very pretty , we didn't go inside it was Sunday when we saw it and service was going on . It's pretty on the outside .
The church is well maintained, accessible and invites participation. Exceptional bapistry, organ and pulpit, all complimented by the petition area where you are invited to pray.

Malmo itself is not a big city, though it's the third Swedish town. So, when you see such building like this, it's always catching your eye. Enormous one, it's even difficult to fill it in a standard photo snap. Must see.
This is an old church with lot of architectural details. worth a visit while in Malmo. The place is not far off from the square.

I wanted to see it as it was the oldest building in Malmo, so I went in a September afternoon. The construction is in well shape, nice architectural elements. Too bad it was crowded by other buildings. I couldn't enter as it was closed...strange for a church to be closed without
Interesting example of a Swedish church. Very interesting mosaics on the wall in the forward part of the church.
Lovely small chapel area to the left of the main door as you go in with amazing frescos over the walls and ceilings. Impressive font with large silver bowl.
A beautiful piece of architecture and not one to be missed while in Malmo. Very easy to find from the square or the train station.

We dropped in and managed to catch the last of Sunday services. It was wonderful. Oh sure, it's not Saint Peter's or Westminster but it's a great representation of some of the larger, more ornate churches in Sweden.

What a splendid church! Walking in, I saw a little area for toddlers to play - how cute! In the back corner of the church I felt like I was going back in time. You can see the beautiful murals on the walls, knowing that you are viewing art from so long ago. Also, look down---

Maybe it's just us, but walking into a church while a mini orchestra is practising and a small playground for toddlers is provided isn't something you come across everyday. Plus a list of all the known priests that served there since the 15th century really gives you a feeling
Beautiful building. Impressive inside and outside. Very close to railway station and old town. Very original building material for someone more used to sandstone edifices.
A restored 1950's organ is played for the public Wednesday's at 12:10. The hearing of such a fine instrument being played is inexpressible.
It's was beautiful well worth a visit. Easy to find in the center of the city within walking distance to all other attractions.

Visited this church in the weekend and I could even witness a christening of a child. This church is full of impressive architecture. In a free leaflet in the church (in a couple of languages) you can read about the history of the St. Petri church.
Open to the public, located right in Malmo so easy to get to, Easy to find just follow the main spire.

Walking distance from the Central Station. This church is 800 years old and looks majestic. Seeing the outside was enough but when you step inside, you will awe struck by the beautiful architecture, murals and decor. The interior decoration is stunning and priceless. Starting

We nearly missed the original murals that are being revealed in one corner of the church. The puritans had white-washed the walls and the original murals had remained covered for many years. They have now been revealed in one section of the church and it was fascinating to see
Free entry to this beautiful well maintained church. Great architecture so building is stunning before you even see inside!
St Petri Church, is a special place. Stunning architecture and decor. Beautiful stained glass windows, and amazing ceilings.

I love old churches, and this one was breathtakingly beautiful inside! I can only imagine getting married in one of these awesome churches. It was free admission, but we did make a small donation. The pictures here do not do it justice. Very peaceful and serene. A short walk
It is a must visit if you like places full of history. It is an 800 years old beautiful church and the best of all the entrance is free. If you are in the area, don't forget to pass by.

The church is close to Malmo's train station and easy to visit while walking towards (or returning from) the city center. It is not big enough for an extended visit, but there is enough to see to keep you busy for 15-30 minutes. There is a kids corner in the back of the church

While I was there a man sat at one of the many pianos in the church and started playing very gently. It added to the respectful atmosphere in the church. It is a big church with a magnificent high altar of oak timber, but covered in gold leaf. There is a merchant's chapel with
We live close buy, I often forget what an amazing place this is. Can hold its own among cathedrals all over Europe. Stop buy if you, entrance is free.

If you are in Malmo, this church is well worth a visit. It is near the train station, close to the little squares in Malmo. The church is old and beautiful. You can buy a broshure for 5 korons (approx 0.50 euros). Have a pleasant stay in Malmo!

This is the first church that greeted me as I left the train station. It stood majestically and really looked so beautiful. The interior was beautiful and impressive too. Pop in and have a look, it's worth the time.

I have had the pleasure and benefit of having this church as my congregate church and both of my daughters are baptised there. It´s a really nice contrast to the city centre outside. Beautifully preserved and well worth a visit with it´s impressive history. Suitable for all
It is Sweden's oldest church. It is beautiful and well kept, quite impressive. Worth checking it out if you're in town..
Nice place. Visit it if you're in Malmö. It's located near the little square and was free of charge when we went there. Also, it is close to the metro.
This is a very beautiful bulding from the outside and even nicer inside. It has some lovely carvings and is quite impressive. Well worth a visit.

I was surprised by the church...it was very Catholic in feel...crucifix with Jesus's body, a Madonna statue, ornate altar...but I found out it was a Luther church...the structure survived the purge of the Reformation... A must see...

For art history enthusiasts this is a must - a very stylish church built in the Gothic style and the entry is free of charge. I happened to be there at noon and there was even a concert going on which was enjoyed by tourists and locals alike.
The church is very centrally located, not far from the centre and the main railway station. Nice inside, so calm and quiet. The interior is extremely light.
I think this is the biggest church in town. Building started build in 1319. Inside are a lot of very interesting artefacts from 16-th and 17-th century.
Beautiful Church but the desk attendant seemed to not want to be bothered with questions. Would have loved to learn more but the entrance had no English language pamphlets srocked.

Looking for some peace and quiet away from the shopping streets of Malmö? This is the place to go and marvel at the sheer size and grandeur of the all-white interior of this magnificent church. Well worth a visit!

Take the time to visit this church. Go inside. There is no cost to enter, but they are accepting donations to complete the largest organ in a church in Scandinavia. The main ceiling is not very ornate, but there are some lovely pieces of religious artwork to admire. This is
Churches are not in much use these days in weathier parts of europe like sweden. But this old chruch, surprisingly, is very beautiful in its interior and definitely worth a visit.
This is a beautiful interior and well worth looking inside. At the time we visited they were playing pipe organs which was interesting.
Lovely alter. Very impressive. At the end of the school year teachers and students meet here for celebrations.
We still find each new church a wonderful experience. St John's certainly did not disappoint us during our visit to Malmo. Certainly would recommend you discover its wonderful interior.
Very impressive church. Was nice to sit and contemplate the architecture. Bit late to take advantage of the coffee that is available to visitors.
An ice little medieval church in the corner, quiet and peaceful. The wallpaintings are amazing. But to see its famous organ, you have to go to the city museum.
On a Saturday in May it wasn´t easy to find an occasion to visit the church, as it was very popular for weddings. Murals in side chapel worth the visit though.
Unique design that varies alot from other cathedrals in Europe. I walked by it every day on my way to the convention center. It was locked, however, and I never got to take a peak inside.

It was a good surprise visiting this attraction while I was on the way to the central station walking. Got inside easily and it was full of beautiful art works..! Man and Woman, the tower was soooo big at least 200 to 240 feet if I am not wrong..!
This old (built in 1319) charming church is worth popping into. It is light and airy with little fuss, but attractive interior and exterior. Lovely calm welcoming atmosphere.

We had an excellent tour guide who explained the history, design and uses of the church. The ornate inside is even better than the the outside with the beautiful paintings and old grave slabs with their inscriptions still visible. The massive chandeliers and the acoustics are

If you need to find a quiet place then go inside. You can light a candle. Choose a peaceful corner and be still. There might be a little midday service. Or maybe you are lucky to see a baptism in the left corner at the church.
This is the whitest church ⛪ I have ever seen and I have seen some white churches. There is a alcove with original murals on which is very good.
Highly recommended for those who love seeing old churches - very beautiful! We walked by once before it opened (10am) but came back and were happy we did!

We went to this church as it is only minutes away from the station. On the outside, the church is obviously not as large as most famous cathedrals but the architectural design is unique and very sophisticated. The tower up front looks taller than expected. The walls and pillars

We checked the church and found that most of the interior had been in a process of whitening through great many resent years. Only a little part has been saved and this was interesting to experience. The atmosphere in the church is 'cold' and our first impression was that the
It's quite a big, bright church on the inside. Don't let the outside full you with all the brown bricks. It's worth a visit but to me nothing special.

This is a lovely church with a light bright interior- it felt fresh. The religious iconography was displayed to maximum advantage against the white paint. The arches are tall and graceful and the person on the desk is helpful and knowledgeable- well worth stopping by.
Lovely church - light and bright inside with some interesting frescos. If you are lucky (as we were) you might arrive just at the right time to get a free cup of coffee!

Visited this church today, it's 700 years old & worth the visit! Gorgeous interiors draped in history, unfortunately we visited the church as a funeral was being prepared so we cut our visit short as we felt a little uncomfortable being in there and taking photos with grieving
I stumbled upon this when the bells were ringing. Beautiful church. You could hear the bells a mile away. A must see even if you aren't religious.

This is the oldest church in Malmö. Of course it is beautiful, with soaring height, breathtaking architecture and carvings and a hushed atmosphere. But it's more than that. There is a small Chapel on the left side, Krämarkapellet, with a christening font, and walls covered in
First time to visit this Old Church its so beautiful inside.my family enjoyed very much .the originality of the interior design inside the Church was excellent.

This awesome church is a perfect example of how awesome brick gothic can be. This type of gothic style only occurs in Baltic state countries and Skandinavia so it's a great chance to visit it while spending time in Sweeden.
This beautiful 700 year old church is definitely worth visiting. It's beautiful inside! They were testing the organ when we stopped in and it sounded gorgeous. Worth the stop!
It's a church like many other. I found the altar strange: it's very baroque, very golden. it looks strange among the plain white walls. There's a play corner for kids, and free tea/coffee.

Malmö was cold and windy. I was on my way to the Moderna Museet, when I saw this church, so I went in to warm up a little. They serve free tea, which was very nice in this cold weather. St Petri is the oldest church in Malmö, built in the 14th-century. The Krämarkapellet has

We stopped by the church while we were visiting Malmo for the day. It was open and we could look around, the inside is stunning.There is also free coffee available. In all we spent about 20 minutes walking around the inside and taking pictures.

I promised myself to visit this church in Malmo and see the difference between the nordic churches and the ones in Italy or anywhere in the Med. Indeed, this church has all the lines you would expect in churches I saw in Sweden, UK, even Germany and Austria...... plus the

When we stepped inside the church we were stunned by the interior of this church, didn't expect it to be so bright inside. There was also a free concert available for everyone to enjoy at 7pm, unfortunately we had a train to catch so weren't able to stay for that. We did see a

I stopped in while walking by one evening as I heard music / singing from inside. Stepping in I was blown away by the acoustics and the fullness of the performer's voices. It was a free concert (held frequently) and was well worth the time. The church itself is a thing of beauty

This is a really nice church, I visit churches not so much for the religious side of things that I enjoy taking photographs of the architecture. They are very friendly there unless there is a service on where they are further that you don't go walking around which I guess is

I was on a hired bike so didn't want to leave the bike for very long, so I only peeped inside. I was amazed just how light it was, as normally churches are dim and cold. Certainly next time I will stay longer as it is a beautiful church.
Very beautiful place with devine athmospere inside. Worth seeing for sure, because this is aming the few really interesting places in Malmo

Ducked in here to escape a snowstorm. Really peaceful space, with information leaflets in English for those who are interested. The large wooden altar is apparently one of the largest in the country - and the smaller altars are lovely, too.

A nice church with a beautiful interior. Worth to take a small stop and walk around. It was nice to sit down for about 20 mins. I spent the time gazing the interior and listen to the choir practicing. It was quite a good experience.
The largest church in Malmo city centre, with interesting stained glass and decor. Free to visit and very close to the old quarter, it's a good rainy day option.
This church have white clean lines, but with very special golden decoration. Some times there are concerts free for the public.
Nothing special but i liked the inside. Overall average. If u don't go, you miss nothing. Nothing much to see in Malmö anyway.
not too overdone, spacious, nice artwork, impressive for a small town. if you're short on time and have seen nice churches before, feel free to pass on this one.
We have visited at lunch time and there is a show, and free of charge. We have stayed for the show and was very nice.
A tip: in the center of Malmö, behind the largh square Stortorget, there's a beautiful church : St. Petri!

It's a small church but it's beautiful inside and out. Take a walk all the way around and see some of the remnants of the old church before they tore down the old Catholic art and whitewashed the walls. Free coffee and water is available for visitors, but don't carry it around

This old church is lovely and absolutely worth a wander through. The buttress architecture reminded me of a cathedral in Palma Mallorca and the open door welcomed me in. Donate 2SEK and you can light a candle too.
An active parish of the Swedish Church. We were there at their 1210 srrvice. If yiu enjoy architecture thus church has buttresses. The interior will take you back to the Renaissance.

Wandering around Malmo I had little plans for my visit to the city, and stumbled across this church while taking a stroll around the city centre with this behind the City Hall. It's worth taking a look around the inside of the Church as it is a lovely quiet whitewashed interior.

This church is located right behind the beautiful city hall. Some parts of the church look modern while others fairly old, including carvings on the floor and drawings on the ceiling of one side-room. It's free to enter, and worth a 5-10 minutes look if you're in the area.
It's a nice change from the barrage of churches that you often get in Europe, with a white interior to contrast the more traditional brick exterior.
I had my Sons Christening in this church, the facilities are wonderful with midaeval parts and lovely painted windows. Very specious and friendly staff.

We had travelled from Copenhagen to Malmo, a 35 minute ride by train and were wandering with no where in particular in mind to visit. This is when we came upon a 700 year old kyrka or church, St Petri (Peters). It's different from other cathedrals because the interior is totally

While visiting Copenhagen we made a trip to Malmo. While walking around Malmo, this church is worth a peak inside. It's free. Why not? There was one side room in particular I found the most interesting. The walls and floor made it seem much older than the rest. Check it out if

The church was hosting a wedding, but they very kindly let us have a look around for 10 minutes before it was to start. The outside of the church is wonderful with a very high spire. The inside beautiful - open, spacious, airy, peaceful. Definitely worth a wander around in
Here you can enjoy a before and after the renovation that makes thoughts how did they think? Music sat elected times and art exhibitions

We visited the church on a one day trip to Malmo from Copenhagen. Walking around the inside of the church and learning the history was fascinating. The wonderful pictures painted on the walls and ceiling many centuries ago had all been paired over white on the advice of an
Our hotel was very close to St. Petri's Church and we went there a number of times to enjoy the history and beauty. If your in Malmo it's a must see I would say!
Well worth a visit, we popped in and they were rehersing some drama. Very atmospheric, lovely plain interior to one of Malmo's oldest churches, deceptively simple interior.
A magnificent building, pristine white finish inside with colourful carving adorning the walls. Excellent seating and whilst we were there the pianist played for a service- an absolute bonus.
St. Petri church in Malmö has a really nice exterior and has simple interior. It's worth visiting if you are in Malmö since it's in the center.
Stumbled on this church just walking down the street! Would've been a shame if we missed it it's a Beautiful church inside and out! Worth a visit when in Malmo!

This place is well worth a trip. The building has been well looked after and you are given free access to look around. The only restriction is flash photography. Photos come out really well as the walls are all painted bright white. There is a section of the walls were

This church building is very tall and beautiful to look at. It is the first major attraction that I came across on my first visit to Malmo. Although it is the oldest building in Malmo, it has certainly stood the test of time and its beauty has been preserved. This building has
Beautiful church in central Malmö, have a seat and feel the piece inside the church, only a few people here on a sunny day
This church is really old, dating back to the 14th century. However as much as it is impressive from the outside it is a bit dull from the inside. Nothing much to be seen in it.
Spending a rainy day in Malmo I decided to check out St. Petri. I really enjoyed this church. Only few people and I just sat a enjoyed the peacefulness and beauty of the church.

It was built in 1312, and not too much chenged over the centuries just the tower. It is from 1891, 105 meter high and almost impossible to make a good photo. The altar, the baprtistery are renaissance gems. When they renovated in the middle of the 19. centruy, they cleaned
Big church but somewhat boring. Hardly any people inthere, not that many decorations. Would visit other churches first and save this one for last

This church is visible for a long distance. The outside of the church is as interesting as the interior, but it still is a functioning church and you can have a few moments of quiet meditation during brief morning services.
Lots of stained glass windows in this beautiful church. The outside is just as impressive as the inside.
Very clear architecture, nice church with btight large paces. The frescoes of the gothic chapel are of especially high value
Large, stunning church with a wonderful interior. From the copper roof to the old wooden pews this church has a lot to offer.

For those who appreciate centuries old buildings, this is a must-see in Malmo, full of history and opportunity for quiet reflection. The epitaphs of tombs in the floor are worth a look, even if your Swedish is nonexistent, and the altar of course is very impressive.

After such a long walk around the city of Malmø in Sweden- I always end-up my day for a short period of solitude.A moment to be alone in my own thoughts and to refresh myself.So I choosed a church.Its like going back to old ancient times.Its a travel way back hundreds of years

This is a beautiful cathedral that is a short walk from anything in the city. It is well worth a stop and see--very beautiful. The structure is in good shape--well maintained. There is staff available for questions.

If you have the slightest interest in historical monuments St. Petri is a must when you visit Malmoe. Just inside - and to the left you find "The Merchant's Chapel" with the original wallpaintings including the heraldry of "Arma Christi" dated to the last period - just before
Our first visit in Scandinavian church. My knowledge about this culture and their religion was poor,pretty poor. I imagined to meet with Odin and Thor inside. Thanks for lighting me.
If you are visiting the city, I suggest you to visit this church located in city center, not far away from main train station. Gothic style, this church is good example of medieval era.
This is an interesting building, both outside and inside. Even if you are not religious, we would recommend a visit.

The interior of the church is worth a visit. Very white interior with beautiful artifacts and decorations. One of the few churches where you don't see any stain glass yet still being a very beautiful church. It is a working church where there are recitals every Wednesday

This was a beautiful church but not on the order of some off the more grand European churches. We were in and out in 15 minutes and it was very nice. Worth a visit if you are in town but I wouldn't travel long distances to get here.

St Petri aka St Peters Church is on a quiet street in the middle of Malmo, and easily accessible by foot, bus or train. The outside of the church is pretty ordinary, but the size is nevertheless impressive. The real wonder of this place is only apparent when you walk through the
Impressive church in the middle of Malmo that can quite clearly be seen from most places. Lovely design, the architecture is quite impressive.
This church is amazing both inside and outside. Some of the alcove areas have amazing ceiling paintings. The sculptures in the middle are also inspiring.
A nice white church - very clean - Great Organ - interesting paintings - lots of graves under the floor - nice benches for praying
I passed this church while wandering around Malmö and didn't go inside. The exterior is impressive, especially the tower.
This church was easy to get to and you can take photos inside. I would recommend you to bring cash to buy a one of a kind candle.

text.wiki:
Malmö (; Swedish: [ˈmâlmøː] (listen); Danish: Malmø [ˈmælmˌøˀ]) is the largest city in the Swedish county (län) of Skåne (Scania). It is the third-largest city in Sweden, after Stockholm and Gothenburg, and the sixth-largest city in Scandinavia, with a population of 316,588 (municipal total 338,230 in 2018). The Malmö Metropolitan Region is home to over 700,000 people, and the Øresund Region, which includes Malmö, is home to 4 million people.Malmö was one of the earliest and most industrialized towns in Scandinavia, but it struggled to adapt to post-industrialism. Since the construction of the Öresund Bridge, Malmö has undergone a major transformation, producing new architectural developments, supporting new biotech and IT companies, and attracting students through Malmö University and other higher education facilities. The city contains many historic buildings and parks, and is also a commercial center for the western part of Scania.


== History ==

The earliest written mention of Malmö as a city dates from 1275. It is thought to have been founded shortly before that date, as a fortified quay or ferry berth of the Archbishop of Lund, some 20 kilometres (12 miles) to the north-east. Malmö was for centuries Denmark's second-biggest city. Its original name was Malmhaug (with alternate spellings), meaning "Gravel pile" or "Ore Hill".
In the 15th century, Malmö became one of Denmark's largest and most visited cities, reaching a population of approximately 5,000 inhabitants. It became the most important city around the Øresund, with the German Hanseatic League frequenting it as a marketplace, and was notable for its flourishing herring fishery. In 1437, King Eric of Pomerania (King of Denmark from 1396 to 1439) granted the city's arms: argent with a griffin gules, based on Eric's arms from Pomerania. The griffin's head as a symbol of Malmö extended to the entire province of Scania from 1660.
In 1434, a new citadel was constructed at the beach south of the town. This fortress, known today as Malmöhus, did not take its current form until the mid-16th century. Several other fortifications were constructed, making Malmö Sweden's most fortified city, but only Malmöhus remains.

Lutheran teachings spread during the 16th century Protestant Reformation, and Malmö became one of the first cities in Scandinavia to fully convert (1527–1529) to this Protestant denomination.
In the 17th century, Malmö and the Scanian region (Skåneland) came under control of Sweden following the Treaty of Roskilde with Denmark, signed in 1658. Fighting continued, however; in June 1677, 14,000 Danish troops laid siege to Malmö for a month, but were unable to defeat the Swedish troops holding it.
By the dawn of the 18th century, Malmö had about 2,300 inhabitants. However, owing to the wars of Charles XII of Sweden (reigned 1697–1718) and to bubonic plague epidemics, the population dropped to 1,500 by 1727. The population did not grow much until the modern harbor was constructed in 1775. The city started to expand and the population in 1800 was 4,000. 15 years later, it had increased to 6,000.

In 1840, Frans Henrik Kockum founded the workshop from which the Kockums shipyard eventually developed as one of the largest shipyards in the world. The Southern Main Line was built between 1856 and 1864; this enabled Malmö to become a center of manufacture, with major textile and mechanical industries. In 1870, Malmö overtook Norrköping to become Sweden's third-most populous city, and by 1900 Malmö had strengthened this position with 60,000 inhabitants. Malmö continued to grow through the first half of the 20th century. The population had swiftly increased to 100,000 by 1915 and to 200,000 by 1952.


=== 1900–1969 ===

In 1914 (15 May to 4 October) Malmö hosted the Baltic Exhibition. The large park Pildammsparken was arranged and planted for this large event. The Russian part of the exhibition was never taken down, owing to the outbreak of World War I.
On 18 and 19 December 1914, the Three Kings Meeting was held in Malmö. After a somewhat infected period (1905–1914), which included the dissolution of the Swedish-Norwegian Union, King Oscar II was replaced with King Håkon VII in Norway, who was the younger brother of the Danish King Christian X. As Oscar died in 1907, and his son Gustav V became the new King of Sweden, the tensions within Scandinavia were still unclear, but during this historical meeting, the Scandinavian Kings found internal understanding, as well as a common line about remaining neutral in the ongoing war.
Within sports, Malmö has mostly been associated with football. IFK Malmö participated in the first ever edition of Allsvenskan 1924/25, but from the mid-1940s Malmö FF started to rise, and ever since it has been one of the most prominent clubs within Swedish football. They have won Allsvenskan 23 times in all (as of February 2018) between 1943/44 and 2017.


=== 1970s and later ===
By 1971, Malmö reached 265,000 inhabitants, but this was the peak which would stand for more than 30 years. (Svedala was, for a few years in the early 1970s, a part of Malmö municipality.)
By the mid-1970s Sweden experienced a recession that hit the industrial sector especially hard; shipyards and manufacturing industries suffered, which led to high unemployment in many cities of Scania. Kockums shipyard had become a symbol of Malmö as its largest employer and, when shipbuilding ceased in 1986, confidence in the future of Malmö plummeted among politicians and the public. In addition, many middle-class families moved into one-family houses in surrounding municipalities such as Vellinge Municipality, Lomma Municipality and Staffanstorp Municipality, which profiled themselves as the suburbs of the upper-middle class. By 1985, Malmö had lost 35,000 inhabitants and was down to 229,000.The Swedish financial crises of the early 1990s exacerbated Malmö's decline as an industrial city; between 1990 and 1995 Malmö lost about 27,000 jobs and its economy was seriously strained. However, from 1994 under the leadership of the then mayor Ilmar Reepalu, the city of Malmö started to create a new economy as a center of culture and knowledge. Malmö reached bottom in 1995, but that same year marked the commencement of the massive Öresund Bridge road, railway and tunnel project, connecting it to Copenhagen and to the rail lines of Europe. The new Malmö University opened in 1998 on Kockums' former dockside. Further redevelopment of the now disused south-western harbor followed; a city architecture exposition (Bo01) was held in the area in 2001, and its buildings and villas form the core of a new city district. Designed with attractive waterfront vistas, it was intended to be and has been successful in attracting the urban middle-class.
Since 1974, the Kockums Crane had been a landmark in Malmö and a symbol of the city's manufacturing industry, but in 2002 it was disassembled and moved to South Korea. In 2005, Malmö gained a new landmark with completion of Turning Torso, the tallest skyscraper in Scandinavia. Although the transformation from a city with its economic base in manufacturing has returned growth to Malmö, the new types of jobs have largely benefited the middle and upper classes.
In its 2015 and 2017 reports, Police in Sweden placed the Rosengård and the Södra Sofielund/Seved district in the most severe category of urban areas with high crime rates.


== Geography ==
Malmö is located at 13°00' east and 55°35' north, near the southwestern tip of Sweden, in the province of Scania.
The city is part of the transnational Öresund Region and, since 2000, has been linked by the Öresund Bridge across the Öresund to Copenhagen, Denmark. The bridge opened on 1 July 2000, and measures 8 kilometres (5 miles) (the whole link totalling 16 km), with pylons reaching 204.5 metres (670.9 feet) vertically. Apart from the Helsingborg-Helsingør ferry links further north, most ferry connections have been discontinued.


=== Climate ===

Malmö, like the rest of southern Sweden, has an oceanic climate. Despite its northern location, the climate is mild compared to other locations at similar latitudes, mainly because of the influence of the Gulf Stream and also its westerly position on the Eurasian landmass. Owing to its northern latitude, daylight lasts 17 hours in midsummer, but only around seven hours in midwinter. According to data from 2002–2014 Falsterbo, to the south of the city, received an annual average of 1,895 hours of sunshine while Lund, to the north, received 1,803 hours. The sunshine data in the weather box is based on the data for Falsterbo.Summers are mild with average high temperatures of 20 to 23 °C (68 to 73 °F) and lows of around 11 to 13 °C (52 to 55 °F). Heat waves during the summer arise occasionally. Winters are fairly cold and windy, with temperatures steady between −3 to 4 °C (27 to 39 °F), but it rarely drops below −10 °C (14 °F).
Rainfall is light to moderate throughout the year with 169 wet days. Snowfall occurs mainly in December through March, but snow covers do not remain for a long time, and some winters are virtually free of snow.


== Transport ==

Öresund Line trains cross the Öresund Bridge every 20 minutes (hourly late night) connecting Malmö to Copenhagen, and the Copenhagen Airport. The trip takes around 35–40 minutes. Additionally, some of the X 2000 and Intercity trains to Stockholm, Gothenburg, and Kalmar cross the bridge, stopping at Copenhagen Airport. In March 2005, excavation began on a new railway connection called the City Tunnel, which opened for traffic on 4 December 2010. The tunnel runs south from Malmö Central Station through an underground station at the Triangeln railway station to Hyllievång (Hyllie Meadow). Then, the line comes to the surface to enter Hyllie Station, also created as part of the tunnel project. From Hyllie Station, the line connects to the existing Öresund line in either direction, with the Öresund Bridge lying due west.
Besides the Copenhagen Airport, Malmö has an airport of its own, Malmö Airport, today chiefly used for domestic Swedish destinations, charter flights and low-cost carriers.
The motorway system has been incorporated with the Öresund Bridge; the European route E20 goes over the bridge and then, together with the European route E6 follows the Swedish west coast from Malmö–Helsingborg to Gothenburg. E6 goes further north along the west coast and through Norway to the Norwegian town Kirkenes at Barents Sea. The European route to Jönköping–Stockholm (E4) starts at Helsingborg. Main roads in the directions of Växjö–Kalmar, Kristianstad–Karlskrona, Ystad (E65), and Trelleborg start as freeways.
Malmö has 410 kilometres (250 mi) of bike paths; approximately 40% of all commuting is done by bicycle.


=== Ports ===
The city has two industrial harbors; one is still in active use and is the largest Nordic port for car importation. It also has two marinas: the publicly owned Limhamn Marina (55°35′N 12°55′E) and the private Lagunen (55°35′N 12°56′E), both offering a limited number of guest docks.
Public transport consisted of a tram network from 1887 until 1973. Afterwards, it was replaced by a bus network.


=== Malmö S-Train ===
A local train line with circular traffic at seven stations was opened in December 2018. The stations are Malmö Central Station (underground platforms) – Triangeln station – Hyllie station – Malmö South/Svågertorp – Persborg – Rosengård – Östervärn – Malmö Central Station (main overground terminus). Some trains arrive from Kristianstad and finish with a lap around Malmö, whilst other trains at this circular line, never drive outside the city limits. There is at least a 30 minutes service between each departure, but far more between the Central Station and Hyllie. Extension plans of a minor network system exists.


=== Proposed metro ===
The Öresundsmetro is a proposed rapid transit network linking Malmö with the existing Copenhagen Metro through a 22 km tunnel under the Öresund.


== Municipality ==

Malmö Municipality is an administrative unit defined by geographical borders, consisting of the City of Malmö and its immediate surroundings.
Malmö (Malmö tätort) consists of the urban part of the municipality together with the small town of Arlöv in the Burlöv Municipality. Both municipalities also include smaller urban areas and rural areas, such as the suburbs of Oxie and Åkarp. Malmö tätort is to be distinguished from Malmö stad (the city of Malmö), which is a semi-official name of Malmö Municipality.
The leaders in Malmö created a commission for a socially sustainable Malmö in November 2010. The commissions were tasked with providing evidence-based strategies for reducing health inequalities and improve living conditions for all citizens of Malmö, especially for the most vulnerable and disadvantaged and issued its final report in December 2013.


== Demographics ==
Malmö has a young population by Swedish standards, with almost half of the population under the age of 35 (48.2%).After 1971, Malmö had 265,000 inhabitants, but the population then dropped to 229,000 by 1985. The total population of the urban area was 280,415 in December 2010. It then began to rise again, and had passed the previous record by the 1 January 2003 census, when it had 265,481 inhabitants. On 27 April 2011, the population of Malmö reached the 300,000 mark. In 2017 the total population of the city was 316,588 inhabitants out of a municipal total of 338,230.In 2019, approximately 55.5% of the population of Malmö municipality (190,849 residents) had at least one parent born abroad. The Middle East, Horn of Africa, former Yugoslavia and Denmark are the main sources of immigration. In addition, 14.8% (50 999 residents) of the population in 2019 were foreign nationals.Foreign-born population by country, 31 December 2018:

Greater Malmö is one of Sweden's three officially recognized metropolitan areas (storstadsområden) and since 2005 is defined as the municipality of Malmö and 11 other municipalities in the southwestern corner of Scania. As of 2019, its population was recorded as 740,840. The region covers an area of 2,522 square kilometres (974 sq mi). The municipalities included, apart from Malmö, are Burlöv, Eslöv, Höör, Kävlinge, Lomma, Lund, Skurup, Staffanstorp, Svedala, Trelleborg and Vellinge. Together with Lund, Malmö is the region's economic and education hub.


== Economy ==

The economy of Malmö was traditionally based on shipbuilding (Kockums) and construction-related industries, such as concrete factories. The region's leading university, along with its associated hi-tech and pharmaceutical industries, is located in Lund about 16 kilometres (10 miles) to the north-east. As a result, Malmö had a troubled economic situation following the mid-1970s. Between 1990–1995, 27,000 jobs were lost, and the budget deficit was more than one billion Swedish krona (SEK). In 1995, Malmö had Sweden's highest unemployment rate.However, during the last two decades, there has been a revival. One contributing factor has been the economic integration with Denmark brought about by the Öresund Bridge, which opened in July 2000. Also the university founded in 1998 and the effects of integration into the European Union have contributed. In 2017 the unemployment rate is still high but Malmö has, in the last 20 years, had one of the strongest employment growth rates in Sweden. But a lot of those jobs are taken by workers outside the neighboring municipalities.As of 2016, the largest companies were:
Skanska – heavy construction
Nobina – transport
PostNord – postal services
Pågen – bakery
IKEA – furnitureAlmost 30 companies have moved their headquarters to Malmö during the last seven years, generating around 2,300 jobs. Among them are IKEA who has most of its headquarter functions based in Malmö.The number of start-up companies is high in Malmö. Around 7 new companies are started every day in Malmö. In 2010, the renewal of the number of companies amounted to 13.9%, which exceeds both Stockholm and Gothenburg. Especially strong growth is in the gaming area with Massive entertainment and King being the flagship companies for the industry. Among the industries that continue to increase their share of companies in Malmö are transport, financial and business services, entertainment, leisure and construction.


== Education ==
Malmö has the country's ninth-largest school of higher education, Malmö University, established in 1998. It has 1,600 employees and 24,000 students (2014).
In addition nearby Lund University (established in 1666) has some education located in Malmö:

Malmö Art Academy (Konsthögskolan i Malmö)
Malmö Academy of Music (Musikhögskolan i Malmö)
Malmö Theatre Academy (Teaterhögskolan i Malmö)
The Faculty of Medicine, which is located in both Malmö and Lund.The United Nations World Maritime University is also located in Malmö. The World Maritime University (WMU) operates under the auspices of the International Maritime Organization (IMO), a specialized agency of the United Nations. WMU thus enjoys the status, privileges and immunities of a UN institution in Sweden.


== Culture ==


=== Film and television ===
A striking depiction of Malmö (in the 1930s) was made by Bo Widerberg in his debut film Kvarteret Korpen (Raven's End) (1963), largely shot in the shabby Korpen working-class district in Malmö. With humour and tenderness, it depicts the tensions between classes and generations.  The movie was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film in 1965. In 2017, the film Medan Vi Lever (While We Live) was awarded the prize for best film by an African living abroad at the Africa Movie Academy Awards. It was filmed in Malmö and Gambia, and deals with identity, integration and everyday racism.The cities of Malmö and Copenhagen are, with the Öresund Bridge, the main locations in the television series The Bridge (Bron/Broen).


=== Theatre ===
In 1944, Malmö Stadsteater (Malmö Municipal Theatre) was established with a repertoire comprising stage theatre, opera, musical, ballet, musical recitals and experimental theatre. In 1993 it was split into three units, Dramatiska Teater (Dramatical Theatre), Malmö Musikteater (Music Theatre) and Skånes Dansteater (Scanian Dance Theatre) and the name was abandoned. The ownership of the last two were transferred to Region Skåne in 2006 Dramatiska Teatern regained its old name. In the 1950s Ingmar Bergman was the Director and Chief Stage Director of Malmö Stadsteater and many of his actors, like Max von Sydow and Ingrid Thulin became known through his films. Later stage directors include Staffan Valdemar Holm and Göran Stangertz. Malmö Musikteater were renamed Malmö Operan and plays operas and musicals, classics as newly composed, on one of Scandinavia's large opera scenes with 1,511 seats. Skånes dansteater is active and plays contemporary dance repertory and present works by Swedish and international choreographers in their house in Malmö harbor.Since the 1970s the city has also been home to independent theatre groups and show/musical companies. It also hosts a rock/dance/dub culture; in the 1960s The Rolling Stones played the Klubb Bongo, and in recent years stars like Morrissey, Nick Cave, B.B. King and Pat Metheny have made repeated visits.
The Cardigans debuted in Malmö and recorded their albums there. On 7 January 2009 CNN Travel broadcast a segment called "MyCity_MyLife" featuring Nina Persson taking the camera to some of the sites in Malmö that she enjoys.
The Rooseum Center for Contemporary Art, founded in 1988 by the Swedish art collector and financier Fredrik Roos and housed in a former power station which had been built in 1900, was one of the foremost centers for contemporary art in Europe during the 1980s and 1990s. By 2006, most of the collection had been sold off and the museum was on a time-out; by 2010 Rooseum had been dismantled and a subsidiary of the National Museum of Modern Art inaugurated in its place.


=== Music ===
In 1992 and in 2013 Malmö was the host of the Eurovision Song Contest.


=== Museums ===

Moderna Museet Malmö was opened in December 2009  in the old Rooseum building. It is a part of the Moderna Museet, with independent exhibitions of modern and contemporary art. The collection of Moderna Museet holds key pieces of, among others, Marcel Duchamp, Louise Bourgeois, Pablo Picasso, Niki de Saint Phalle, Salvador Dalí, Carolee Schneemann, Henri Matisse and Robert RauschenbergMalmö Museum (Malmö Museer) is a municipal and regional museum. The museum features exhibitions on technology, shipping, natural history and history. Malmö Museum has an aquarium and an art museum. Malmöhus Castle is also operated as a part of the museum.
Exhibitions are primarily shown at Slottsholmen and at the Technology and Maritime Museum (Teknikens och sjöfartens hus).Malmö Konsthall is one of the largest exhibition halls in Europe for contemporary art, opened in 1975.


=== Architecture ===

Malmö's oldest building is St. Peter's Church (Swedish: Sankt Petri). It was built in the early 14th century in Baltic Brick Gothic probably after St Mary's Church in Lübeck. The church is built with a nave, two aisles, a transept and a tower. Its exterior is characterized above all by the flying buttresses spanning its airy arches over the aisles and ambulatory. The tower, which fell down twice during the 15th century, got its current look in 1890. Another major church of significance is the Church of Our Saviour, Malmö, which was founded in 1870.
Another old building is Tunneln, 300 metres (1,000 ft) to the west of Sankt Petri Church, which also dates back to around 1300.
The oldest parts of Malmö were built between 1300–1600 during its first major period of expansion. The central city's layout, as well as some of its oldest buildings, are from this time. Many of the smaller buildings from this time are typical Scanian: two-story urban houses that show a strong Danish influence.Recession followed in the ensuing centuries. The next expansion period was in the mid 19th century and led to the modern stone and brick city. This expansion lasted into the 20th century and can be seen by a number of Art Nouveau buildings, among those in the Malmö synagogue. Malmö was relatively late to be influenced by modern ideas of functionalist tenement architecture in the 1930s.
Around 1965, the government initiated the so-called Million Programme, intending to offer affordable apartments in the outskirts of major Swedish cities. But this period also saw the reconstruction (and razing) of much of the historical city center.Since the late 1990s, Malmö has seen a more cosmopolitan architecture. Västra Hamnen (The Western Harbor), like most of the harbor to the north of the city center, was industrial. In 2001 its reconstruction began as an urban residential neighbourhood, with 500 residential units, most were part of the exhibition Bo01. The exhibition had two main objectives: develop self-sufficient housing units in terms of energy and greatly diminish phosphorus emissions. Among the new building's towers were the Turning Torso, a skyscraper with a twisting design, 190 metres (620 ft) tall, the majority of which is residential. It became Malmö's new landmark. The most recent addition (2015) is the new development of Malmö Live. This new building features a hotel, a concert hall, congress hall and a sky bar in the center of Malmö. Point Hyllie is a new 110 m commercial tower that is under construction as of 2018.


=== Other sights ===

The beach Ribersborg, by locals usually called Ribban, south-west of the harbor area, is a man-made shallow beach, stretching along Malmö's coastline. Despite Malmö's chilly climate, it is sometimes referred to as the "Copacabana of Malmö". It is the site of Ribersborgs open-air bath, opened in the 1890s.
The long boardwalk at The Western Harbor, Scaniaparken and Daniaparken, has become a favorite summer hang-out for the people of Malmö and is a popular place for bathing. The harbor is particularly popular with Malmö's vibrant student community and has been the scene of several impromptu outdoor parties and gatherings.


=== Annual events ===

In the third week of August each year a festival, Malmöfestivalen, fills the streets of Malmö with different kinds of cuisines and events.
BUFF International Film Festival, an international children and young people's film festival, is held in Malmö every year in March.
Nordisk Panorama – Nordic Short & Doc Film Festival, a film festival for short and documentary films by filmmakers from the Nordic countries, is held every year in September.
Malmö Arab Film Festival (MAFF), the largest Arabic film festival in Europe, is held in Malmö.
The Nordic Game conference takes place in Malmö every April/May. The event consists of conference itself, recruitment expo and game expo and attracts hundreds of gamedev professionals every year.
Malmö also hosts other 3rd party events that cater to all communities that reside in Malmö, including religious and political celebrations.


=== Media ===
Sydsvenskan, founded in 1870, is Malmö's largest daily newspaper. It has an average circulation of 130,000. Its main competitor is the regional daily Skånska Dagbladet, which has a circulation of 34,000. The tabloid Kvällsposten still has a minimal editorial staff but is today just a version of a Stockholm tabloid. The Social Democratic Arbetet was edited and printed at Malmö between 1887 and 2000.In addition to these, a number of free-of-charge papers, generally dealing with entertainment, music and fashion have local editions (for instance City, Rodeo, Metro and Nöjesguiden). Malmö is also home to the Egmont Group's Swedish magazine operations. A number of local and regional radio and TV broadcasters are based in the Greater Malmö area.


=== Sports ===


==== Football ====

Sports in southern Sweden are dominated by football. Over the years the city's best football teams have been Malmö FF who play in the top-level Allsvenskan Malmö FF had their most successful periods in the 1970s and 1980s when they won the league several times. In 1979, they advanced to the final of the European Cup defeating AS Monaco, Dynamo Kiew, Wisla Krakow and Austria Wien (Vienna) but lost in the final at the Munich Olympic Stadium against Nottingham Forest by a single goal just before half time scored by Trevor Francis. To date, they are the only Swedish football club to have reached the final of the competition. Malmö FF is the club where for instance, Bosse Larsson and Zlatan Ibrahimović began their football careers.  A second football team, IFK Malmö played in Sweden's top flight for about 20 years and the club's quarterfinal in the European Cup is the club's greatest achievement in its history. Today, the club resides in the sixth tier of the Swedish league system.
FC Rosengård (former LdB Malmö) are playing in the top level in Damallsvenskan, women's football league. FC Rosengård girls have won the league 10 times and the national cup title 5 times. In 2014, they reached the semi-final in Champions League, which they ultimately went on to lose to the German side 1. FFC Frankfurt. Brazilian football player Marta, widely regarded the best female football player of all time, played in FC Rosengård between 2014 and 2017.
At the 1958 FIFA World Cup Malmö Stadion was inaugurated in combination with the opening match of the cup, as World Champions West Germany defeated Argentina 3–1, in front of 31,156, a record attendance for Malmö in general. Another two games were decided at the stadium.


==== Other sports ====
Malmö has athletes competing in a variety of sport.


===== Ice hockey =====
The most notable other sports team is the ice hockey team Malmö Redhawks. They were the creation of millionaire Percy Nilsson and quickly rose to the highest rank in the early to mid-1990s and won two Swedish championships, but for a number of years have found themselves residing outside of the top flight. 


===== Handball =====
A first division handball team, HK Malmö, attracts a fair amount of attendance. 


===== Rugby =====
Rugby union team, Malmö RC, founded in 1954, have won 6 national championships. The club has teams for men, women and juniors.


===== Gaelic football =====
Gaelic football has also been introduced to Malmö. The men of Malmö G.A.A. have won the Scandinavian Championships twice and the women once.


===== Additional Team and Individual Sport =====
Other notable team a sports are baseball, American football and Australian football.
Among non-team sports, badminton and athletics are the most popular, together with east Asian martial arts and boxing. Basketball is also fairly a big sport in the city, including the clubs Malbas and SF Srbija among others.
Women are permitted by the city council to swim topless in public swimming pools. Everyone must wear bathing attire, but covering of the breasts is not mandatory.
